Abstract:

Wildfires are a disastrous phenomenon that cause damage to land, loss of property, air pollution, and loss of human life. Due to warmer and drier conditions created by climate change, more severe and uncontrollable wildfires are expected to occur in the coming years, potentially leading to a global wildfire crisis with dire consequences for the planet. To prevent the spread of wildfires, it is essential to use technology for early detection. One way to achieve this is by detecting smoke before the actual fire starts. In this paper, we present a Wildfire Detection and Alert System that uses machine learning to detect wildfire smoke with high accuracy and sends immediate alerts to users.

Our technology is currently being used in the USA to monitor data from hundreds of cameras daily. We demonstrate that our system has a high true detection rate and a low false detection rate. Our performance evaluation study also shows that our system detects wildfire smoke faster than a human operator.

Introduction:

Every year, wildfires burn millions of acres of land, damage thousands of structures, and cause severe air pollution. Wildfires are disastrous for both human communities and wildlife, resulting in billions of dollars in damages annually. In 2021, there were over 58,000 fires in the USA, burning down 7.13 million acres of land. Climate change, caused by global warming, creates warmer and drier conditions, making soils and vegetation more susceptible to burning and leading to severe wildfires. Studies predict a global increase in large and severe wildfires due to climate change. Wildfires are already difficult to control and mitigate, and if their severity worsens, it will have dire consequences for the planet.

Over the years, technology has been used to analyze various aspects of wildfires, including fire spread simulators and detecting wildfires from satellite data. However, these tools do not aid in early detection and prevention. Cameras providing real-time image feeds have been used by human operators to monitor and identify wildfires, but it is not possible for humans to monitor data accurately around the clock. Machine learning algorithms are more efficient for real-time image-based data and can perform early detection of wildfires by detecting smoke before the actual fire starts.

While there are many early detection products available, they often require specialized hardware, have limited coverage, and have a high false detection rate. We present our Wildfire Detection System, which has a high true detection rate, low false detection rate, and uses only real-time camera data for early detection of wildfire smoke. The human operator only needs to confirm the detection alert, allowing authorities to reach the scene and prevent the wildfire from becoming uncontrollable.

Methodology:

2.1 Data:

We gathered raw image data from Alert Wildfire Cameras, which provides open access to fire spotting cameras in the USA. We collected data from 400 cameras, covering various terrains, over a period of nine months. The dataset consists of 90,000 images, which were labeled with bounding boxes and categorized as wildfire and non-wildfire images.

2.2 Model Architecture:

Our model architecture is designed to extract relevant information at different scales, as smoke can be of varying sizes. We use an architecture similar to FCOS, which is a lightweight and fast backbone network. This allows our system to process near-real-time data from multiple cameras efficiently.
